the purposes of our conversation today we can think of a pod as a container every pod has its own IP address and
that all the pods in that cluster are able to talk to one another and there are a few ways that we can achieve that very specific networking model like
click click click wrong button there we go ha ha so one of the first mechanisms that we
can use to attach our pods to the underlying network which in our case will be a V PC it's something called CNI
which is contain a networking interface and this is an open standard of a pluggable architecture of components
that we can use to wire a container to an underlying software-defined network kubernetes supports a wide range of CNI
plugins and each of these CNI plugins offers a variety of different capabilities here's an example of some
of those CLI plugin so if you're shopping around for an interesting way to connect your containers to the underlying V pcs have a look at some of

the capabilities that they offer some of them require you to deploy an overlay network some of them require access to a persistent data store at the back end
some provide a mechanism to micro segment your containers using network policies so think about what it is
you're trying to achieve and what your requirements are from a deployment compliance perspective and security perspective and potentially choose the
CMI plugin that meets those requirements one of the basic mechanisms for orchestrating network connectivity
within kubernetes is Kubb nets and this is the default mechanism that will be enabled if you deploy a cluster using
the cops utility kubernetes really simple it doesn't provide any advanced capabilities and it doesn't even handle
the cross node communication which as you remember from one of the core principles is something that we need to do what it does do is it makes sure
every pot has an IP address and then it will take the information about those IP addresses and populate the VPC route
tables so that all of the other nodes within the cluster know where to find the the pods that exist across the
cluster there this is great it works very very well it's extremely performant and extremely simple to setup the one
drawback of Kubb nets that we find our customers talking to us about regularly
is that because it relies on the VPC route table and the VPC route table has a limit of 50 routes per route table you
can actually only deploy a cluster of up to about 50 nodes now for many organizations that's more than enough
but for some organizations at the edge there that might not be enough so you might have to choose a different approach to something to be mindful of
one of the other mechanisms that you can use to address that particular challenge and and a number of other challenges
that I brought up on the screen here are overlay networks and I briefly touched on that earlier on some of the cni
providers out there today require you to build an overlay network so this is a network that sits on top of the existing
VPC network and builds a mesh between all the nodes within your cluster and adds additional advanced capabilities to
the to the communication path or in the data path between the the communication of the Ponson why might I use an overlay
network a common example I hear a lot from customers is I didn't size my VP C's or my subnets correctly it might be
at the time when you built your sub no your VP seeing you size your subnets and your VP see that you thought you know what I'm going to have hundreds of ec2

pot if you recall from the rules and the design principles I talked about requires its own IP address so having a
